Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with an offwhite head. Toffee, brown sugar, alcohol, spices, a dash of anise. Its okay, and certainly drinkable, but really has nothing going for it. Its a bit like coffee with sambuca.

I think this bottle is at least a couple years old.  Im not sure why I waited so long to try it.  Maybe because of the large format and high abv along with the fact I never thought I was a big fan of the style.  But this is pretty good and I can see why it might be the standard for the style.  The pour is a deep brown with a lasting foam on top.  The aroma shows a lot of rich caramel malt, cherry twizzlers, and candied dried mixed fruit.  A touch of chocolate and resiny hops round out the scent.  The flavors are; smokey, chocolaty, a little bit roasty, and not as sweet and candy-like as the aroma suggests.  The body is rich and malty but perhaps not as big as expected.  The alcohol is really kept in check.  Nice beer.  I enjoyed this one quite a bit.

Pours a deep brown with a small off-white head. Aroma consists of caramel and nuts. The 10% abv is hidden incredibly well. Taste consists of rich caramel, vanilla, scotch, and roasted nuts. Absolutely delicious and very drinkable ale

Shared bottle @RBNAG-11. Translucent, very dark brown. Rich malt aroma. Balanced and rounded, dark caramel and dark bread. Big malt body. Caramel, dark dried fruits and bread. Firm bitterness. Fully balanced. Pleasant alcohol warmth. Lingering malt ending. Nice all over.
15.10.2011. 0,75l Bottle. Dark brown with white head. Rich body. dark malts. Very good flavours. Good bitterness. Nice malty flavours of malt dry and sweet.

Insane scotch ale!  I havent had too many beers in this style, because I thought I wasnt all that big of a fan of them.  But this offering in the style from AleSmith blew me away!  This is one fantastic beer!  It pours a very dark brown color, actually almost black.  I noticed a bit of a purplish hue, too.  The head is small and doesnt offer much lacing, but then again, beers of this magnitude really dont.  So I wont hold too much about the head against this beer.  After a while though, if I let the beer sit for a few mintues, I did get some light cascading and lacing around the glass (although you cant really see most of it once the glass is set back down on the table).  The aromas are very inviting and complex.  The first characteristic I notice is a dark chocolate scent.  That evolved into some vanilla, bourbon, toasted bread, yeast alcohol and dark fruits.  The body is fairly heavy, but well-balanced and enjoyable.  The flavors are absoutely delicious, with notes of dark chocolate, toasted malts, alcohol, dark fruits, light hops and rye bread.  The finish is sweet, with a slight tang of alcohol and more chocolate.  This is definitely one incredible beer!
Caramelic aroma. Average, frothy, off-white head. Fair lacing. Clear, amber body. Flavor is sweet chocolate, port. Medium to full palate.

Pours near black color. Aroma is of malt, sugar, prune,and other dark fruits.   Flavor is similar to a Belgian debbel.  I can pick up sweeter malts, booze, fig, date, and other dark fruits.  This is a big boy beer.    Bravo

Rating number 1500!! Bottle @ home, tfs vaiz! Aroma is fruity dusty malt, red fruits, some spices.
flavour is quite sweet, with malty red fruits, quite some liquorice with a medicinal porty touch. Also a note of amaretto. Wouldnt call it scotch, but definitely nice. Very intense.

Bottle at home. Dark brown pour, thin tan head. Aroma of madeira, port, some roasted malts, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is warming alcohol, sweet chocolate, port and some bitter roasty malts. A bit thin and boozy, but overall quite nice.
Bottle.  Chocolate malt and coffee aroma.  Dark brown color with moderate head.  Lightly sweet toffee malt and moderate herbal hops flavor.  Very smooth and nicely drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a dark mahogany color with a thin lacing head. Sweet aroma with some vanilla and fig notes. Very sweet, sugary flavor. Dry hop finish but it has a dark chocolate flavor to it. Amazinggg. That is all I can say.

Pours a deep brown with a small off-white head. Aroma consists of caramel and nuts. The 10% abv is hidden incredibly well. Taste consists of rich caramel, vanilla, scotch, and roasted nuts. Absolutely delicious and very drinkable ale. A+  Looking forward to trying more from Alesmith.

Bottle 750ml @ RBNAG-11
Pours deep reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, alcohol and some fruits. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

0.75l bottle @ RBNAG11. Pours a near clear deep deep red body with a small sidesticking bubbly head. The aroma is quite sweet with lots of dark caramel and licorice well packed into a malty base. Perhaps a bit on the sweet side, but really nice. Lively to average carbonation with a fizzing-oily mouthfeel. Nice flavors, and strong flavors! Sweet licorice, malty, burned tones, leafs, nuts, raisins and some alcohol in the finish. Really really nice stuff this!

Bottle from 2010, pours dark brown to black with some head that fades and leaves lacing, nose is raisins,  peat and bready notes. First sip is brown malt, brown sugar and smoke and a touch of coconut. Finish is plesant with some bitterchocolate. Very Nice beer.
Bottle, RBNAG. Sweet caramel aroma. Liquorice, cofffee, teacle. Too sweet for my liking, true to type.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Clear dark red with a small, creamy, off-white film head. Aroma has caramel, Belgian sugar, viniousness, chocolate. Really velvety and nice. Medium carbonation, great dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has lovely milky chocolate, roasted notes, caramel, toasted. Softly warming and vinious. Light sugary, dry, mild bitter. Really amazingly balanced.

Pour dark brown with a tan head. Aroma sweet, spice, dark fruits, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, maple, light smokiness. Taste honey, spice, maple, brown sugar, chocolate, toffee, molasses, some peat. MF full body silky cream with light carb. Overall excellent brew very unique and complex great flavors and well constructed.

75cl bottle. Black colour with a red hue. Aroma is mostly alcohol and malts. Some coffee. Flavour is sweet and laden with malts. Sugar and syrup as well. Some coffee notes as well. Medium long aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma of malt,caramel,yeast, hay and grains. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, brown sugar, grains and biscuits. Medium to full body, average carboantion. Nice classic beer.

Alesmith 
Wee Heavy
Pours dark brown with red highlights. Not a ton of head, but good retention of what is there. Aroma of raisins, chocolate malts and alcohol. Pungent for a Scotch ale and very nice. Flavor is boozy with a pile of malts. Nutty and raisin bran like breadiness is there. Mildly sweet and very good.

GABF 2011. Dark chestnut brown, clear, with a khaki head. Deep musty aroma--chocolate, peat, a touch of heather, molasses, smoke. Taste was nice and deep and large, nearly chewy. Chocolaty with tones of peat, smoke (light), burnt caramel, candy sugar. Warm too. Smooth and tasty, not too sweet. Perfect scotch ale.

750mL corked bottle poured reddish-brown into goblet with big tan head with long retention and lots of fine lacing.  Aromas of roasted malts and smoke.  Taste is smoky roasted malt sweetness and chocolate with some alcohol and hoppy bitter finish.  This is a big, bold beer with lots of character.  Nicely done.

Bottle. Dark brown nearly black with brown head. Aroma very powerfull, malty and some smoke, notes of whisky probably from the smoked malt. Taste sweet malty, some warming alcohol and again smoky notes. A nice beer but gets cloying. Drinking a whole bottle alone would be too much.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 Un bombe maltée aussi complexe que possible pour une scotch ale. En entrée, on a le déluge de malt rôti et chocolat caramélisé. En milieu de bouche, une touche dalcool nous amène vers le caractère fumé assez pointu qui, mélangé avec le kick damertume, donne une progression assez spectaculaire. Fait intéressant, on a presque limpression que le malt est étouffé par le houblon et la fumé dans une combinaison presque piquante sur le bout de la langue. Très curieux de voir la progression dans 2-3 ans dici.

Süffig obgleich schwer malziger Antrunk. Ausgeglichen wird dies durch eine angenehme Süße, die trotz ihrer zunehmenden Steigerung nie penetrant wirkt. Eine gewisse Alkoholnote wirkt angemessen, das Malz weist getreidige Noten auf und wird mit der Zeit tiefgründiger. Etwas holzig, dunkle Schokoladennoten, dabei aber eine gewisse Trockenheit, die sich positiv auswirkt und die Süße behindert, die so immer in angenehmem Rahmen bleibt. Erstaunlich milder Abgang mit weicher, dennoch intensivem Malz. Wenig holzig. Ein super Bier! 10/12/12/12/9/12

750mL bottle.  Pours very dark brown, completely opaque, with small foamy head that leaves a nice tan halo that sticks around for quite a while.  Nose is quite malty sweet, caramel, chocolate.  Thick, sticky, creamy, caramel and chocolate; finishes with a very nice alcohol warming.

(750ml bottle from cloudskipper, sampled 6/20/11). Clear dark amber color. Large off white head. Moderate caramel and bready malt aroma and flavor, with moderate alcohol. Long duration. Moderate to strong alcohol finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Pour dark brown, with a small beige head.
Aroma is heavy, filled with vanilla, syrup, brown sugar and dark fruits. 
The taste is heavy on the sweet side, but still very balanced. 
Nice medium body, with a rather oily texture, with the perfect amount of carbonation.
Very well executed.

Brownish red pour with a medium sized tan head. Malty aroma with the smoke coming through. Taste of vanilla, malt, caramel, raisin and a slight smokiness. Great creamy mouthfeel with the perfect carbonation rounding out this great beer.

On tap @ the brewery.
Reddish brown with very little head.  Aroma is smoky with carmel malt and rasin.  Flavor is heavy malt with a good amount of sweetness, some chocolate and just a hint of smoke.  An excellent example of the style with a well hidden ABV.

Poured a creamy Dark chocolate color, A small tan white head. slight smokey and malty nose. low carbonation and a little thin on the Palate. Some bitterness, little hop presence before, chocolate, roasted, and perhaps some smoked malt making it balanced.  Nothing overpowering, perhaps some yeast esters.... Peat? Alcohol is well hidden. Taste has a mixture of sweet dark fruit, molasses and a bit of light hops. Pretty good, but There are a couple more I rate higher.
Pour is a deep brown with a finger thick tan head. Nose is of sweet dark fruits. Taste is very fig like, with a date presence as well.Rather heavy, though the alcohol is well disguised.

Thick mahogany pour with a thick tan head. Wonderful aroma aroma of toffee, chocolate and a hint of smoke. Taste is nice and chewy, notes of chocolate, toffee and even the slightest hint of cherry and smoke. Simple, well done easy drinking brew and a great example of the style.

as soon as you open the bottle tons of caramel malts pour out from the beer.  It smells a little bready but mostly caramel and touches of chocolate.  It pours a dark brown body with a white fluffy bread that leaves behind decent lacing.  It tastes very sweet, almost like a mix of old chub and a nice brown ale.  Again very full of caramel in the taste and hints of coffee and chocolate.  The beer is very smooth with medium to low carbonation.  This beer paired well with pulled pork bbq and coleslaw to cut into the sweetness.  I could only drink about 1 pint maybe 2 if really streching my sweetness level.  Overall not my favorite style of beer but a good beer, not great, that I could see myself drinking when the right time came about.
Pours a midnight black with very little head.  Aromas of coffee and caramel.  Initial warmth that warms to a sweet roasted finish with hints of alcohol.  A wonderful, wonderful beer.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a dark brown, nearly black with a greyish head of foam. Aroma is birch, vanilla, and a slight musty character. Taste is birch and vanilla up front, moving on to a long, mellow malt finish. I loved every sip of this beer.
Black with a red hue body. Honey and raisins in the nose. Very sweet taste, caramel, molasses, perhaps a bit too sugary and unbalanced.

From memory. 2006 bottle. Aroma was smoke, caramel, toffee, alcohol. Taste was caramel and toffee, dry and smoky. Sweetness had faded out and turned into an amazing sipping ale. Nice heat from the alcohol. After five years this has turned into an amazing beer.

Shared bottle at Sigmunds summer tasting. Clear deep ruby with a creamy, beige head. Dried fruits, malts and caramel on the nose. Sweet, fruity, alcoholic, malty, bitter, light salty and liquorice present. Well balanced, full bodied drink with an oily and smooth mouth feel. Delightful.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a clear chestnut brown color with a medium sized creamy beige head.  The aroma is sweet caramel, hints of peat and smoke, butterscotch (but not in a bad way), vanilla and some mild fruits.  The flavor is sweet caramel, vanilla, hints of tart ripe fruits, buttery toffee and a nice smoky finish.  This drinks very smooth with a medium plus body.  I cant believe that I hadnt rated this yet.

Bottle at cgarvieuks. Pours black with a 1 1/2 finger head. Nose is of vanilla and raisins, with a noteable sweetness. Taste is interesting, a touch of bourbon, with dark fruits/raisins. Sweet chocolate and caramel is also present. Body is a touch thin for my liking, Id prefer a wee heavy to be more, well, heavy, but aside from that, this is a very solid, nice drink.

Bottle shared at cgarvieuks. Hazy deep brown with a medium off-white head. Big raisins & liquorice on the nose. Some vanilla. Palate is also rich, rum and raisin! Sweet chocolate & chewy caramel finish. Surprisingly thin body, but a complex, enjoyable sipper.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Smokey, what I assume is peaty flavor, dark fruits, light roast maybe, butterscotch, slightest hint of cacao, maple syrup. Not as creamy as I excpected though. Balanced taste. I know it was exposed to less than desirable conditions for a few hours. Still quite good for a malt bomb.

Bottle at Craigs, thanks Ben. A dark red colour with a thin light tan head. Nice sweet caramel aroma with liquorice, raisins and vanilla. Chewy caramel flavour also with raisins, candy sugar, stewed fruits and malt. Alcohol is fairly present in the flavour but also lingers. Reminded me of rum and raisin chocolate.
(Bottle 29/06-2011) Light brown head, clear dark brown, creamy mouth feel, a bit high alcohol.
Pretty black with some nice redness shining through. S: Honey, malt and alcohol. T: Sweet, malty. P: Thick.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours dark brown with a thin tan ring around the edge. Smell is butterscotch, vanilla, and sweet caramel and chocolate. Taste is roughly the same, with a butterscotch finish and a bit of roasty sharpness. Smooth and full-bodied. Nice.

Dark brown/mahohany color with a nice beige head. Nice bubbles along edge of glass that lasted awhile. Nose was not particularly strong. Flavor was carmel, dark fruit, figs. Very, very smooth and balanced. Creamy mouthfeel. High drinkability.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with small creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma with notes of dark fruits and licorice. Sweet vinuis flavor. Creamy palate.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a very deep red with a head somewhere between off-white and light tan.  Smoky, peaty aroma, earthy, some berry aroma.  Flavor combines the peaty earthiness with very tasty red grape, nuttiness, smoky touches, toffee.  A little cocoa comes out later.  I wondered just what a Scotch Ale would have to taste like to be rated this highly; now I know.

Bottle:
Small creme bubbly lacing on top of an almost black beer, with a red/ruby shine.
Smell molasses, syrup, honey, dark spices and dark fruit.
Taste toasted malts, barleys, dark fruits, sticky, molasses, some hops and herbs but mostly dark and good sweet.
Nice dark fruity light bitter light sweet aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a sticky texture. Not bad, but expected a bit more.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Dark brown with a deep dark red glow. Large bubbles in a light beige head. Taste kind of sweet, little alcoholic, but very nice. Body ok, carbo medium.

Fundamentally excellent beer. Big, huge flavors. Nice sweet malt, light peaty smoke flavor, and just enough hops to keep it in check. Could maybe use a little more hops, as the flavor is just a little too sweet. Overall, an absolutely incredible scotch ale, with an incredible flavor. Biggest criticism is that the nose had very little going on.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Pours dark chestnut brown. Strong malt nose. Caramel, toffee, vanilla, slight smoke. Quite sweet, heavy body. Very tasty. A true showcase of great malt flavors 4.5


Re-rate 10/02/13. Bottle. Very dark brown with tan head. Dense aroma, lots of dried fruit, raisins, prune, dates, molasses, caramel and vanilla. Similar flavours,  lots of dried fruit and caramel, so rich. Heavy and sweet with just a touch of fruity alcohol. Bangin 4.6
Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is quite sweet, heavy malty and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish with warming alcohol. 290611

75 cl bottle kindly shared by Abemorsten. Pours dark ruby with a small white head. Aroma is strong malty, vinous, chocolate and traces of smoke. Taste is malty, chewy,thick malts with alight smoked addition. Moderate sweet lingering aftertaste. Full bodied and fully drinkable.

750 ml bottle, kindly shared by abemorsten. ABV is 10%. Very dark ruby colour, nearly black. Low beige head. Aroma of malts, dark dried fruits / prunes and caramel, maybe a hint of smoke. Very rich and malty flavour, again with caramel and prunes, and maybe a hint of smoke. Powerful stuff.

750ml bottle. Reddish brown, medium tan head. Plum and prunes, malt, mild peat and smoke. A great balance of flavours with the scotch and malt complimenting each other well. Sweet on the palate - raisins, finishes like its aged in wine barrels - some hops that cut the sweetness and leave a great finish that is slightly dry. Very good.
75cl, American brew, from Bierkompass Stolberg, complex Scotch, smoked and slightly sweet, yet not too heavy, very balanced, clear, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Deep red/chestnut brown color, small creamy head. Aroma has sweet liquorice, nuts, winegum, booze, leather, sugar, tiny bit of chocolate. Slightly perfumed and chemical, but nicely balanced. Taste has roasted nuts, bright milk chocolate, subtle and adequate alcohol, some malty sugar, slightly roasted malts and toasted wood. Very complex malt-profile but nicely balanced. Excellent.
rich caramel/alcohol aroma with hints of pine, malty rasiny flavor with light hop bitterness and finishes with a nice chocolatey aftertaste

Dark dark brown.  Aroma is somewhat medicinal, comprised of cherry, slight butter, huge sweetness, molasses.  Palate is syrupy and thick.  Flavor is sweet, chewy, butter, molasses.  A minimal hop bitterness briefly tasted in the finish.  A bit much for the summer months, but still lovely.
Pours dark, with a thick beige head. A well balanced beer with caramel, malty, and smokey flavor. A really enjoyable beer, with a hint of deep whisky flavor in the finish.

Purchased a bottle in California, consumed after the Bruery release party. Thanks ME!

Beer served in a Bruery tulip. Beer is brown and pretty hazy with a big off white head of small bubbles. Head falls away quickly and leaves some lacing on the glass. Carbonation is high, looks good.

Mildly caramelly, mildly peaty, mildly sweet, smells good but I wanted more volume.

Beer is medium bodied and has a lot of carbonation on the palate. Its sweet up front with some caramel notes in the midpalate region and follows it up with nice malt presence and clean finish that isnt dry. Drinkability is high and I really liked this beer. Im very interested in the barrel aged version of this beer now because I think this would take the barrel notes well, more wood more alcohol, sounds good to me.

Serving type: bottle

Bottled 75cl. Hazy brown with a nicely lacing beige head. A lot of caramel throughout. Exceptional balance. Full bodied. Nice malt profile. Boletus sneaking in. Complex. Late subdued bitterness. Definitely a good, flawless beer with plenty of character. Slightly overrated to my tastes.

Bottle, split between a lot of people. Poured black with a very small head. Aroma of dark malts, chocolate, caramel, a touch of smoke, a touch of coffee. Flavor was very stout-like at first with coffee and roasted malts, but a smokey scotch flavor came out in the finish. Thick mouthfeel, kind of chewy, very complex. Lots of stuff going on with this one but it all comes together nicely.

Bottle from a trade with alen. Pours medium brown color with light brown head. Aromas of toffee and caramel, slightly roasty with a hint of smoke. Similar flavors. Medium body with soft carbonation. Very nice. Thanks alen.

Very complex, malty nose: toffee and caramel, raisins and dark ripe fruits, roasty malts, chocolate and molasses, a bit earthy and smoky.  Pours an almost opaque deep burgundy, lots of tan head and great retention, some lacing.  Flavor takes a while to absorb and dissect as there is so much going on.  Sweet malt character dominates, with caramel, toffee, and chocolate coming in strong.  Roasty, smoky and earthy flavors enhance the malt profile as well.  Dark sugars, molasses, plums, raisins, dates; lots going on with the fruit flavors.  There is also some supporting bitterness, but just enough to provide some balance for all of the malty, sweet character in this juggernaut.  Very full-bodied with low carbonation, very slick, creamy and chewy.  Such a complex and interesting beer, this is definitely worth seeking out.

Bottle shared by Tampabrew, danka.  05/6/7?  This was, for me, very interesting.  Its like my tongue was quickly ascending stairs of subtly different flavors.  Its pretty damn massive, I wasnt ready for it and it got cracked early in the evening.  Most complex Scotch ale Ive had.  Try it.

dark mahogany, light red in the middle, great color, light tan head rises a couple fingers, really nice lacing... nose is too weak but there is some really nice caramel on the front, then fades to some light peat and molasses, a sweeter scotch ale just not strong enough to get one excited, as it warms gets a lot sweeter... the taste is really disappointing, light caramel with some smoked peat on the finish, bland and boring and the barrel aged is just so much better I can barely recommend even trying this

Pours a fading rim of beige head with a dark brown body that has a ruby hue in the light.  Aromas of brown sugar, some roasted qualities, and cereal grains.  Flavor is much the same.  Finish is heavy, malty, brown sugar, slightly dry.

750ml bottle split with McBerko. Pours a ruby brown with a nice frothy tan head. Aroma is exquisite. Softly roasted caramel malts, chocolate, molasses, bread, dark fruits, and smoke. Flavour features rich, toffee malt, layers of fruit that taste like they were soaked in port. Viscous mouthfeel is fat, malty, smooth and creamy with a crisp carbonation. Finish is lightly sweet, bitter, and smokey. Outstanding and hands down the best scotch ale I have ever had.

Bottle. Dark brown body with a medium light brown head. Aroma is nuts, malt, caramel, dark fruit and chocolate notes. Flavor is milk chocolate, malt, light hops, caramel notes of dark fruits. Alcohol is well hidden. Beautiful lacings. I didn´t have that high expectations on this beer.

750mL bottle, split with manuchampions, pours dark mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma is very intense: rich dark fruits, heaps of caramel, candied sugar and scotch whiskey. Flavour is no less robust, with extremely rich caramel, rich dark fruits and a strong scotch-like whiskey finish. Thick, viscous, sticky body, with an uncompromising palate. AleSmith delivers again - phenomenal.

Pours chestnut brown with a red hue and a really nice khaki head. Aroma is nutty malts, sweet liquorice, chocolate, caramel, leather notes and a bit winey. Taste is delicious roasted nuts and milk chocolate, dark fruits like dates and figs, a hint of alcohol, nice burned bread crust, toasted wood. Extremely complex malt profile and the balance is outstanding.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 A redish black beer with a brown head. Aroma of nuts, leather, sweet caramel malts, sweet liquorice and light alcohol. Taste of chocolate, nuts, liquorice, caramel, light roast, toasted woods and some alcohol here aswell.
Sampled in the bomber. Aged for around two years. Really enjoyed this brew great scotch ale. Malts are really nicely balanced with good hops. Awesome.

Pours a very deep dark chestnut brown color with ruby/mahogany edges and a frothy two finger beige head with excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Chunks of soapy lacing left behind.

Very smokey roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate, oatmeal, hazelnut, burnt toast and roasted espresso bean. Theres also a bit of sweet dark fruit but the nose is dominated by the roasted character.

Chewy full body with a blast of dry roasted malt up front that lingers throughout over the sweeter malt and dark fruit notes into a lingering dry finish. Slightly bitter with some earthy hops and acrid burnt toast flavor as well as hints of chocolate, hazelnut, oatmeal, toffee and coffee bean. Im picking up some licorice and dark fruit mid-palate, especially plum and raisin that provide some much needed balance to the heavy roast character. There is some slight heat and warmth in the finish but the ABV is well masked. Dry fnish.

Overall, this beer is pretty complex and flavorful but its a touch too roasted tasting for my liking. Its still a very good beer but I wish there was a bit more sweetness to balance things out.

Bottle.  Aromas of caramel malts....lots of it.  I also get notes of some peat smokiness like a scotch whisky.  Beer pours a dark brown with a light brown head.  Head goes quickly.  Heavy mouthfeel, very thick and full.  The flavors are very rich and the malts are what really strike you on this one.  Big ABV, but not really noticed in the taste.  Overall, this is a great Scotch Ale.  If you like them, give this a try.

Some tasting notes from a couple weeks ago...Ive been slacking on my RB!

Dark reddish-brown in color with moderate head.  Aroma is candi sugar and loads of caramel.  Flavor similar with crazy caramel malt and cloying sweetness, which confused me as to how this is the highest-rated scotch ale in the world.  High ABV is well hidden, however.

Its not you, its me. Im just not that into the "extreme" beer movement. This beer is a fine beer, certainly far more than passable, but the most noticeable thing about it is the alcohol. On the upside, it is wonderfully balanced, but maybe a bit too much so - a little unbalance might have helped.

Had this and a BA Wee Heavy side by side for comparison. This poured brown with small light beige head.  It has an aroma of toasted malts, toffee, and caramel. The flavor is caramel, toffee, nuts, wood. Yet another great AleSmith brew.

On tap at the ritual in san diego. Pours a mahogany full body and thin head with subtle lacing. Smells like scotch, malts, citrusy hops, and scotchy scotch scotch. Tastes like rich malts, bitter hops, some oats, and scotch. Very good. The mouth is very thin and dry with an alcohol finish.

Bottle; bomber, many thanks to Scopey. Cheers mate!!

On appearance nice white lacing; covers most of hte surface, gorgeous black texture, very nice eye candy indeed.

Aroma is pure tonnes of marzepan; sweet candi(y?), figgs, raisins, floral hops, fresh bread, barely. oatmeal, spices and cinnamon.

Taste is very complex. Typical Alesmith assertiveness, heavy on the malt, toffee, chocolate, raisins, loads of oats, cinnamon, spices, tough chewy bread, barely, candi-sugar, marzepan, figs, quite unbalanced but very interesting and a little rough on the palate but generally a very fine and very nostalgic brew. Something which should even out fabulously aged a year or two. Im really fascinated. So much complexity in this and another brew from Alesmith I can ponder with over the wee small hours. Scotch ale?? COME ON!!!!
Bottled sample that survived the plane ride.  Was thankful for its survival as this was one of the finest beers I have ever tasted

Poured from a 750.  Dark cola color with a nice head.  The nose is malt, smoke, peat, and malt.  Taste is malt, caramel, smoke, malt, and more malt.  This is my favorite beer from a kick ass brewery.  I would be shocked if I taste any other Scotch Ales that surpass this.

Poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Very dark brown, nearly black color. Two full fingers of cream colored creamy/frothy hybrid head. Good retention and a small ring of lacing.

4.0 S: As this warms up it becomes very nice. Roasty, toasty, and some smoke are readily apparent. Somewhat grainy and a bit bready as well. Brown sugar, toffee, and a touch of booze. The aroma could be stronger though.

4.0 T: Taste is a bit better than the nose, but deserves the same score. Only a touch of roastiness, toastiness, and smoke. Dark roast crystal malt is very apparent. Some raisin/tobacco and date fruitiness in there. Brown sugar and toffee again. The alcohol is extremely well hidden.

4.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Very creamy and smooth. My only issue with the mouthfeel is that the carbonation isnt spritzy enough and the beer lies heavy on the tongue.

4.5 D: Maybe Ive been drinking too many big beers lately, but this doesnt seem as flavorful as it could be. The nose and taste are good, but could use a little extra power. Overall, this beer is pretty good and the alcohol isnt found anywhere in the taste, making this beer quite drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-20-2010 23:49:24

fresh bottle side by side with the 09 ba version. actually the first time i have ever tried this brew! lol! very good stuff. there is some cardboard like oxidation in the nose that seems off, but then lends wonderfully to the flavor of the brew. very nice and balanced, with the signature alesmith complexity and refinement. low to medium carb, excellent finish and mouthfeel. this brew has showed me that oxidation flavors can lend to a brew in a great way.

Best non-McEwans Scotch Ale/Wee Heavy I have tried and found.

THIS is what the style should taste like. Exceptional head, foamy and rich.

Dark, sweet, STRONG rich sipper with some caramel, molasses, vanilla, and just a wee bit too much coffee. Sweetness is perfect.

Alcohol level makes it vaporize quickly off the tongue - McEwans leaves a bit more tarry syrup behind, which I like.

They should really bottle this in some smaller bottles with some plaid on the label because this is the best Scotch Ale in America by far, and I think the best one still available period.
Dark pour tiny head. Very malty and somewhat roasty. Pretty daen good for the style.

Dark brown body with a thin tan cap but given the 10% thats ok. Roasted malts, molasses, hints of soya sauce, burnt sugar and I even hit some coconut but that doesnt seem correct. Taste is much the same with burnt sugar heavy dark malts, hints of peat, plum, mild soya. I also get burnt marsh mellow. Very tasty, complex, and high quality. The 10% was completely hidden.
bread, toffee,alcohol, dark/red,clear, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, alcoholic,long finish,

Brown with a red note in colour, with sediment,, particles, hazy. Has a light brown head, medium duration. Aroma is heavy sweet, toffee, caramel, sweet sherry. Flavor is heavy sweet too. More toffee, light chocolate. texture is heavy creamy, syrupy.
Bottle. Dark brown with small beige head. Flavour is malt, caramel, dark fruit, yeast, spices and hops.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly lasting head. Red-amber colour. Heavy malty and light hoppy aroma. Strong toffee and caramel notes. Moderate bitter nice powerfull flavor. Average bitter long nice finish. Creamy palate.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are syrop, caramel, dark fruits, chocolate, malt and hops.

Pours dark brown with an orange/brown head. Aroma is nutty, woody, and very chocolaty. Some molasses and raisins, a little roasted malt. Flavor is more dark fruit forward with big raisins, molasses. Chocolate and wood in the background. Alcohol is only moderately felt. The mouthfeel is  silky and beautiful. Pretty sweet yet complex beer. Loved it.

Thx Brad! Pours a medium to deep brown brew, a small medium tan head that leaves a ring and a bit of spotty lacing. Killer aroma! Big caramel, sweet!, molasses, nuts, plum, toffee, almond, white chocolate, red licorice and roasted malts. Smelling this made me drool many times. Lots of roast in the taste, fruit cake, toffee, light spice, chocolate, pepper, plum and lots of things. Smooth with no real notice of the 10%. A treat of a beer.

Bottle; Pour is Dark Brown with Amber Highlights. Average Khaki head with above average retention and light lacing. Aromas of chocolate, scotch, toffee, dark fruits, and molasses. You have to notice just how palatable it is - wonderful really - love the creamy full feeling; chocolate, raisins, toffee, smoked barley, scotch work wonderfully together. There is a hint of booziness at the end, but that is quite alright. Love it!

aroma: alcoholic with chocolate and coffee hints with raisins.
appearance: dark brown to black, very dark, minimal head, resides quickly
taste: little sweet, more alcoholic than a beer. light bitterness with chocolate and coffee hints smokey at the end.
palate: med to full bodied, average carbonation, smokey finish.
had high expectations, still a good sipper beer.

Pours a dark ruby with a frull creamy head and very attractive lacing left behind.  The aroma is dominately chocolate with some sweet dark fruits.  This one has very rich sweet malts with chocolate and caramel malts coming through as well as vanilla, sweet raisins, a touch of smoke in the finish as well as the finish being a bit dry from the roasted malts and the hops are felt as well.  Overall, this beer is rich with a dry bitter finish.  Very enjoyable.
Tap at Alesmith. Looks like Coca Cola. Rich slightly fruity nose. Medium bodied and a bit fizzy. Lots of dark fruit. Very tight. Very good, but not quite great.

Pours a dark brown color with a bubbling head. Aromas and flavors change as the beer warms up, Smells of cherry, toffee and carmel. The taste is nutty with some mild hops lingering in the background.  This beer is quite drinkable for the style and the ABV. Another great one from Alesmith.

750ml bottle from Brewdog Aberdeen. Pours a deep brown with thin tan head. Nose; caramel malt, sweet dark fruits, lots of liquorice and leather. Taste; malty, caramel, brown sugar, dark chocolate, rasins, good alcohol warmth, with a smokey aftertaste. A complex, rich and well balanced beer.
Bottle courtesy of Dallas. Pours a deep amber murky body. Aroma is sweet malt, scotch and yeast. Mouthfeel is thick and chewy with great notes of scotch, oak, and creamy vanilla.

Bottle pours deep brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel/toffee, light roast, tobacco, and leather.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of smoke and maybe even some vanilla.  This stuff is amazing as expected from Alesmith.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with very minimal head. Flavor is heavily malt forward, notes of roast, brown sugar, smoked malts, hints of bourbon and oatmeal. Very thick on the palate with a lingering sweetness and hints of alcohol on the back of the throat. Full bodied, lingers long on the palate after the last sip. Definitely one of the better Scotch Ales on the market. Blurs the boundary between stouts and ales.

Bottle with patfannon and jredmond. Pours a coffee black with a brown head. Nose is a a slightly Smokey peat. Taste is awesome. Creamy vanilla with a nice rounded toasty malt. Very dark tawny flavor with the most minimal hint of booze. Extremely well balanced. Thinking of buying one for cellaring. Great brew.

Pours a deep brown with rich off-white head. Incredible lacing. Aroma is a wonderful array of peat, bubblegum, caramel and grassy hops. The taste, while rich, is a bit one note. Lots of chocolate, some dough and thats about it. Flavor lingers a bit. Alcohol completely hidden.
This is a good beer, but I would take an Old Chub instead.
Bottle thanks to DaSilky. Shared by me at Jimmacks awhile back. Pours almost black, dark brown. Nose and taste of chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, toffee and sweet malts. Very well balanced.

Big 750 bottle poured into a tulip.  Dark chestnut brown pour with an off white tight head.  Faded quickly leaving a nice collar around the glass, decent lace.  Aroma was rich caramel malts, somewhat nutty with a light dark fruit presence.  Flavors were big time caramel, a slight roastiness, light booze, slight sweetness with a light bittersweet finish.  Mouthfeel is just about perfect for this style, big and rich, smooth as can be, carbonation light but present.  Nothing fancy about this one, straight forward and to the point and executed in expert fashion.

Enjoyed many times on tap and in bottle.  This one is bottle.  Heavy thick brown in the glass with a thick and solid tan head.  Aroma is heavy, sweet malt, raisin, caramel, and some smoke in the final 1/3.  Taste is buttery smooth caramel, molasses, perfectly balanced rich and sweet malts (but not too sweet or hot), and some raisin notes.  No noticeable alcohol at any point of the taste.  Another gem from one of my favorite local breweries.

Thanks to multiple traders for sending bottles of this out my way.

Pours a very deep brown with a medium tan head. Several fingers quickly turn into a slight lacey ring. Nose is quite complex with caramel, brown sugar, raisins, brown sugar, miscellaneous dark fruits, and a bit of alcohol. Taste is similar, but not as strog nor as complex. Good solid body wihout much heat. Drinks nicely now; Im looking forward to pulling out another one in a year or two.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-01-2010

Another alesmith beer!  Hope it is as good as the previous few!  Pours a brown color with a light brown head.  Smells a bit sour with some brown sugar sweetness.  Taste is a bit matly with a little bit of that sourness mixed into the flavors.  Very interesting taste as I believe this is my first Scotch ale.  I dont mind a little sourness mixed in with the beer and this one doesnt over do it.  Has some nice sweetness at the finish of this beer that balances it out nicely.

Rating #100.  750 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a 3 finger tan head that has good retention and leaves a large amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is caramel with a bit of roastiness, smoke, tobacco, leather, and licorice.  Taste is strong with malt, tobacco, smoke, and roastiness.  Finish is caramel, more smokiness with just a hint of alcohol.  A licorice aftertaste is left in the mouth.  Medium body.  Light carbonation.  Amazing beer.

Man this thing is intense,not in a overpowering kind fo way but in a complex, so many flavors I could sit around swishing it around in my mouth and find a new flavor each time.  Raisins, alcohol, caramel, chocolate, pepper, toffee, pears, smoky, plums, vanilla, oaky, brown sugar and on and on and on...

750 ml bottle from SouthBay Drugs (San Diego, CA). Been in the cellar for a good while. Pours a rich dark brownish hue, some glowing orange edges, decent haziness, a small frothy brownish almost cola-esque head dies to a film. Aromas are rich toasty malts, biscuits and bread. Some dark fruit dried plums and raisin, vanailla beans, some light peaty smoke. Sweeter, but enticing, rich and warming. Initial is rich and toasty, some smokey peat, rich caramel and toffee, vanilla, breads, dark fruit, some warming alcohol. Rich sweetness, creamy vanilla, soothing toasty bread and biscuits, smoke, dark fruit. A nice full flavor, some cherries. Pretty nice, flavors are strong and potent, supporting the higher ABV frame better than some lacking or underdone Wee Heavys. Finish is dry, lightly bitter with lingering toast, sweet caramel, and soothing and tasty vanilla. All in all, a strong effort by Alesmith. A great beer with rich flavors, fairly bitter and roast/toasty on the backend.. Maybe some faint cocoa, but a lot of caramel, vanilla, peat, dark fruit, biscuits and toast.. Solid

Bottle. Pours a clear and mahogany beer with chunks and an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, caramel and some alcohol. The flavor is close to the nose. The palate has alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer but with a high level of alcohol.

750 mL bottle.  Dark brown, thick pour with a medium tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and faint smoke with caramel and toffee.  Great full bodied taste of toffee, chocolate, roasted nuts with a lasting warming alcohol finish.
Bottle: pours a cola-like dark brown with a frothy tan head, sweet, malty aroma, taste is a touch smokey, some caramel or maybe some coffee, fairly full bodied, pretty amazing beer.
Pours reddish copper with a light brown head. Aroma is caramel, raisin, fruity and light hop. Flavour is caramel, burning alcohol, fruity and raisin.

Seriously  good beer. Poured with a large foamy, frothy, fine, tan head that lasts and good lacing. Color is a hazy mahoganey. Aroma is heavy, volatile mix of malt, peat, dark ripe fruit and toffee. Flavor is like aroma with a sweetness/bitterness balance that is spot on along with the earthiness that works great. Body and carbonation work perfectly together and are full and lush. Finish is like flavor with a fleeting sense of the smoke. The rest of the characteristics actually taper off rather quickly and smoothly, ending with a fairly mild alcohol note considering the strength. Not a session unless youre a glutton.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2010 Poured from a 750ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with tan head.  Lots of lacing.  Sweet, malty, not overly boozy.  Smells of peat, smoke, toffee, caramel.  Tastes of smoked malt, toffee, burnt brown sugar.  I personally think this is Alesmiths best brew.

750 mL bottle from Boston. Pours hazy dark brown with off-head head. Nose of toffee and dark fruits. Lightly smoky with caramel malts. Notes of raisin, plums, cherries, vanilla and oak.  Not overly sweet, and just a fantastic sipping beer.

Bottle looks awesome, beer in the glass the same. Deep black, nice head. Starts very, very strong, heavy-malty, intense notes of liquorice, fiery-alcoholic. FInish a little bit more sourish-earthy, still fiery-malty. Really good beer!

Acquired in a trade, served this in a snifter.  Pours dark brown, almost black with a large, thick, coffee-colored, two-finger head which settled only to a half-finger.  Nose is is some dark fruit (figs, plums)brown sugar and a heavy dose of scotch or brandy. Taste is sweet- brown sugar, toffee, caramel, dark fruits - a little roasted coffee, peat and a liberal dose of scotch/brandy and accompanying warming.  There is a nice bitterness in the end to ameliorate all that sweetness up front.  Mouthfeel is fairly heavy with a decent amount of carbonation.  Watch out cause you certainly arent aware of the ABV.  This is a very nice offering, although Alesmith seems to seldom miss.  They certainly didnt with this one.

1 oz sample at the GABF; then had another.  Great deep reddesh brown, clear.  Nice  cramy head.  Carmel malts with a touch of chocolate and sweet licorice or molasses.  A touch of smoke on the finish  Full body with balanced grassy hop bitterness with malt and alcohol.  Sticky, medium carbonation.

aroma is very sweet and cloying with maple syrup, alcohol, prunes, raisins, vanilla, and oak.
pours a thick brown with quickly receding tan head.
flavor is also predominantly sweet, but not cloying, and is balanced with malty bitterness and alcohol warmth.
heavy body with smooth creamy texture and dry long sweet alcohol finish.
a bit too sweet, but this is great.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2010 Thick dark pour with amazing head that sticks to the side of the glass. Rich caramel sweet flavor that mimics scotch in a candy base. Amazing ale.  Attack!

1 Sept 10: Re-attack. Better than the first time. Solid tones of butterscotch in the first sip - rich butter with sugar lacing the sides. Amazing. Ridiculous.

Bottle. 24.5 oz.. Courtesy of and split with Vin. Pours an amazingly deep, ruby, mahogany brown with a bubbly, rich tan head that fades and leaves lights laces down the sides of the glass. Aroma of tofee, caramel, scotch, vanilla, oak, raisins, figs, dark plums , coffee, toasted malts, barley, and cream. Medium bodied with a rich, yet supple and roomy palate. No stickiness or burn. Finishes smooth and sweet. No alcohol at all in the aroma of flavor. Excellent Scotch ale.
750 ml bottle, shared with Gotta.  Dark ruby brown, large beige head, massive lacing.  Aroma of butterscotch and light spice.  Taste is scotch, vanilla, bitter finish with light pepper.  Nice.

Pours dark chestnut brown, with a small head that leaves lacing.  Aroma of caramel, earth, dark cherries, a little smoke.  Very full bodied with a well balanced flavor profile, not too sweet with the perfect amount of bitterness.  This is such a clean, enjoyable beer, with average carbonation and thick texture, somewhat bitter finish and smoky finish.  The 10% ABV is well masked, just a great tasting Wee Heavy, one of the best Ive had.

Bottle. Muddy tan pour with full khaki head. Aroma is heavy of caramel with notes of rum, oak. Delicious butterscotch flavor with notes of dark rum and oak. Creamy and slick mouthfeel with a blend of sweet butterscotch and sharp alcohol. A lingering caramel-rum-smoke blend. A scotch ale lovers wet dream.

750ml bottle. 2004 Vintage (at least that was when I bought this one!). Pourde a deeper mahogany color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, raisin rum cake, some woodiness, and lighter smoke. Tastes of caramel, raisins, chocolate, nutty, toffee, light smoke,  and all around malty. Alcohol content hidden. Aging well.

Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a dark brown body with tall tan head. Aroma is toffee and some dark fruits.  Predominant flavors of plums, grapes, toffee, vanilla, and a hint of chocolate.   Goes good with spicey food.  Very smooth yet lively in character.

(750ml bottle).  Pours very dark amber/red color with tan head. Aroma of caramel, molasses, and some smoke (mild peat?).  Taste is sweet with some hop bitterness.  Full bodied and creamy texture.  Carbonation is lively and finish is slightly bitter, but long and smooth.  Yes!!  This beer rocks!  I remember having my first scotch style ale many years ago and not caring for it.  I recall it being too malty for me.  This beer is very complex and I keep thinking an aged Rochefort 10.  It has a luscious caramely quality. In my humble opinion, this is a world class beer.  This is the first time I had this beer and I love it!!

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, some smoke, chocolate, fruit, & spice; Flavor of smoky sweet malt, caramel, molasses, dark fruit (notably cherries), chocolate, nuts, and spice; Very nicely balanced & complex; The alcohol is very well hidden; Overall, another great brew from this brewery.

750ml bottle in a thistle.  Pours transparent, deep ruby/brown with a lingering beige head.  Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit/wine, and a hint of smokiness to it.  Nice thick texture and full body.  Sweet, with a long molasses finish.  A really good beer.

Oh man do I like this beer. Pours dark - a cola brown with a tan head. This one has strong, sweet malts on the nose, balanced by a big hop contingent. Tons of flavor - roasted malts up front, with sweet, velvety, smoky caramel following... balance is perfect, though, which I really love about this one - so many scotch ales are so far overboard on the sweetness, with not enough to reel them back in. This one isnt at all like that. Finishes clean - this one is just delicious. Man do I wish I could find this near me.
Wow what abig beer, loaded with Malts , candy, psices, and port wine flaovrs, deep reddish amber, with a great head and some lacing.

750mL into my new thistle! Finally the right glass for a Scotch Ale. Poured a deep, clear, gorgeous ruby with a massive, beyond rocky, almond ice cream head that has absolutely insane retention and lacing of God. The head is so thick that I literally took a few Advil pills and could just rest them on the foam. Fucking unreal. If ever there was a beer to get a 5/5 for appearance, this is it. Nose is rich with maple syrup pancakes, cocoa butter, coconut, cinnamon toast, fresh coffee. As it warms it smells like straight up French toast. Taste is maple, brown sugar, coffee, dark chocolate, perfumey/floral hops show through, spicy alcohol (no warming though). Chewy, thick palate with spicy alcohol and balancing hops in the finish. World class, absolutely the superlative of the style, hands down.

Bottle, thx tarheels. Pours brown with a tan head. Flavor is just tons of caramel, cinnamon, spice with a sweet malt backbone. The 10 percent abv is barely detectable, this beer is immeniently quaffable. Just fantastic.

Trade from HogtownHarry - thanks! Murky red-brown with a little tan head. Aroma is quite something, with beguiling grape and prune and so on. Taste is true to the aroma, with a good bite of hops, some restrained yet ballsy alcohol going on, and endless replays of dry dark fruit and red grape and maybe some lemon. Also some mineral, and some almost perfumey floral thing going on. Grain and malt richness fills in the background. Pretty huge feel to the beer, but always perfectly balanced and never clumsily sweet. Just an excellent really well-made beer.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2010 750ml, silver foiled bottle from south bay. pours a dark, cola-brown with a thick, frothy, khaki head leaving drippy rings of lace. aroma is wonderful with big notes of toffee candy, caramel malts, sweet, bready yeast and light spice with dried fruit notes of fig, apricot, and apple and hints of dusty cocoa. flavor is wonderful with tons of sweet toffee, chocolate, and herbal hops backed by smokey molasses, dried fruits, and roasted nuts with light spice and coffee on the finish. palate is full bodied, lightly carbonated, and offers a solid balance of sweet and smokey flavors. overall, another well crafter beer from alesmith.

Well how does this style rate so high, let me count the ways. Number one, the aroma is incredible. Vanilla, malt everything good. It looks great, dark brown almost black with a small tan head. Flavor is wonderful. Vanilla, malt with a great hop presence. Finish is just as good, warm and inviting. Keep them coming.

Bottle served in a snifter. Pours dark brown in color with a medium-large beige head. Great retention. Aroma is impressive. Malty dark fruit that grows more complex as it warms. Cooked prunes. Full-medium body and classic smooth and malty scotch ale flavors. Great brew.

Brownish cloudy pour with an amber hue tan head ....  Lots of aroma caramel, roasted and a little smoke ..... taste of molasses and caramel, lightly roasted malts and light smoke can detect a little sweet chocolate in there but mostly the caramel and molasses .... light bittersweet finish and highly drinkable for 10% .... Hides the ABV well and is medium to heavy bodied .... Wow

Bottle, 75cl. In the glass, its an almost clear beer, brown in color, and with a pretty, dense, beige head sitting on top. The aroma has alcohol, nuts, caramel, roasted malts and some dark dried fruits. Theres some alcohol in the flavor too, but not as much as in the aroma, yet with a certain warmth. Its full-bodied, with flavors of sweet dried fruits, nuts and caramel, and to back it all up; a lovely hoppyness. Theres some beef-stock too in this one. The finish is both bitter and warming, the sweetness left in the back. A pleasant beer indeed, dangerously easy drinking, and very tasteful. 091230
Bottle. Dark amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, oxidation, roasted malt. Flavour is sweet, roasted malt, oxidation, alcohol, chocolate. Balanced nice beer.
excellent brew.  This beer is very heavy.  Drinks like a syrup instead of a beer.  If your looking for a quick drink.  This isnt it.  Savor this one.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown wooden color with a small gray brown head. Aroma has notes of licorice, chocolate, malts and a hint of alcohol. Alcohol quite present on the tongue with a strong licorice notes and undertones of smoke and chocolate. Quite thick on the tongue.
decaturstevos stevofest part 2. Sample from a bottle thanks to decaturstevo.  Dark red-brown, tan cover.  Potent caramel aroma, fruity.  Taste is caramel, peaty, light smoke, fruity.

Pouring a very dark ruby red.  Settling to about a quarter inch of head.  I smell sweet crystal malts, cherries, raisins, plums and hints of dates as well.  Head is a slight tan/brown color.  Tight lacing all over the glass as well.  Thus far excellent head retention.  Very tight mouthfeel.  Light to medium carbonation.  Just perfect really.  Crushes every other scotch ale I have ever had.  I can taste hops at the end, slight wood characteristic almost, malts coming through wonderfully but not too strong.  Slight cherries, raisins, and other subtle fruit characteristics.  This beer makes is fantastic.  Have not had a bad beer from this brewery yet.

Pours deep mahogany with thick off white head, aroma is big molasses, chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Taste up front is caramel and toffee sweetness leading to a bit more bitter chocolate and finishing with a slight smoke and a dry finish.  Goes down smooth, and there is no sign of 9% ABV in this! Good scotch ale.

An exceptional ale courtesy of Paul (Archimedes something). This beer poured a dark reddish black with a finger of head. The aroma has raisin with a bit of sweet roasted caramel. Taste has a mixture of sweet dark fruit, molasses and a bit of light hops. The sweetness is quite prevalent but not overwhelming. The alcohol is very well hidden. Aftertaste has a good bit of caramel and chestnut. Most likely the best Scotch Ale I have ever had. If you get a chance, you must try this excellent brew.

Alesmith continues to impress (I wish theyd go for some 4-packs!).  Dark and mahogany in color, this scotch ale pours with a moderate head.  Sweet nose.  Flavor is dark roasted malt and the sweetness of figs.  Just a bit of alcohol, but for the most part the ABV is almost entirely masked.  Very subtle smokiness, which I prefer in a scotch ale.  Having a hard time deciding whether I prefer this to the Dark Horse Scotty Karate, which is definitely smokier.  Id say its a toss up.

750 ml bottle (9,5% ABV). A hazy dark brown beer, with an average sized, creamy, mostly diminishing and laciung light brown head. The aroma is quite powerful, heavily malty and lightly hoppy with notes of toffee, licorice, caramel, molasses, chocolate and nuts. The flavour is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Well balanced and smooth, nuttu, toasted. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness, very lightly alcoholic. Wonderful. The best Scotch Ale Ive tasted so far.

Again, thanks to footbalm for sharing this bottle 
Appearance: Dark brown with red tint. Small off-white head leaving no lacing in the glass 
Aroma: Roasted malts, smokey and raisins 
Taste: Dark malts, smoke, dark fruits 
Very nice beer. Enjoyable to drink and well balanced.

750ml:  chocolate color, attractive white head.  slight smokey and malty nose.  low carbonation and thick moutfeel.  some bitterness, little hop presence before crystal, chocolate, roasted, and perhaps some smoked malt perfectly blending with nothing overpowering, perhaps some yeast esters.  alcohol well hidden, adding depth only.  great brew, best ive had of the style, nearly perfect

Flaske: Mørkebrun øl med et hurtigt forsvindende lille skumhoved. Karboneringen er dog god. Masser af chokolade malt i duften. Smagen er også ton på ton chokolademalt. Rigtig fin karbonering og godt humlebid slutter øllen af så den ikke bliver for kvalm af chokolademalten.

Again thx to Bianca and Thierry. For tasting day 20.02.2010. Also this 75 cl. bottle,.
Dark brown color, with a creamy head. 
Aroma strong roasted malts, nuts, bit madeira, complex, like a stout.
Medium to full body.
Taste rich, sweet, strong roasted malts.

bottle, thanks to BavarianPurity, pours dark brown, tall tan head.  Aroma is strong Belgian yeast, brown sugar and green raisins.  Rich malt backbone of carmel and chocolate with some almond nutty character.  Cherries and plums are there, but the fruityness is more in the yeast.  Very lively character, creamy body.  I love it.

Got a chance to try this at my fathers winter place in Mesa, AZ. Very drinkable, malty but surprisingly bright. Both Dad and Shirley, neither who like beer, said they liked this being surprised by how good it tasted and how little they tasted the alcohol.

Bottled. Dark brown pour, ruby highlights, dense tan head. Sweet caramel, smoke, and dark fruit nose. Flavor was sweet malt, smoke, toffee, raisins, and plums. Very low key hoppy finish balanced the sweetness well with some alcohol notes.

Picked this up from Jungle Jims International Market, you gotta love that place they have everything!! Poured into a pint glass, not a thistle and its still just as good Im guessing. This is a dark dark ale with a nice fluffy tan head id like to say. The aroma is wonderful, chocolate, caramel, raisins and a tinge of alcohol. The flavor has a great smoky hint that you dont find in most scotch ales, at least the ones I have tried. My advice is to find this and enjoy the hell out of it like I am. Great Ale!!

On tap at AleSmith Brewing Co. (San Diego, CA): Pours out ruby brown with a nice frothy tan head. Aroma of softly roasted caramel malts, chocolate, molasses, bread, dark fruits, and smoke. Rich, toffeelike malt flavors. A little portlike. Mouthfeel is fat, malty, smooth and creamy with a crisp carbonation. Drinkability: Lightly sweet, bitter, and smokey. And you get those distinct flavors in that order. Pairing: Sticky pudding. Rebuy: Yes. @290 on 25022010, DG.

i first tasted this at the brewery and was blown away... then I picked up a 750mL bottle and really enjoyed it.  i am a fan of scotch ales and this is my new favorite.  like most alesmith offerings, this has great balance, texture, and flavors.  its more hoppy than the average scotch ale, so the hop-averse may not enjoy it as much.

750 ml bottle. Dark brown body with a brown head. Aroma is dominated by roasted heavy malt. Flavor is sweet malt, dark chocolate, roast and a warming Madeira type fruit/alcohol feeling. More warming alcohol in finish together with a fine balanced bitterness. Nice.

Certainly the best scotch ale Ive ever had, but it isnt a style that Im really enamored with.  Heavy on the smoked and sweet malt flavors which compliment the dark red color.  Big and bold and certainly not ashamed about the present alcohol.

Dark brown hue with thick creamy head that sustains. Nose is big malts with slight roast and peat, hints of toffee and molasses. Flavor is sweet malts with hints of smoke, roast, and bread-biscuit, toffee and brown sugar peek through in the middle, finishes slightly sweet with a hint of alcohol warmth. Full body, thick chewy texture, light-moderate carbonation. A totally solid amped up scottish ale with tons of malt flavor an complexity.

2009 Bomber.  Pours dark chocolate brown with a creamy head.  Complex malty aroma that highlights caramel, milk chocolate, toffee, earth, a slight port notes.  Falvor is rich, sweet, yet extremely balanced and flavorful.  Perhaps what caps this beer is its refined bit of noble hops that cut some of the sweetness and adds depth.  Im a big fan; unrivaled for Scotch Ales.

The smell is sweet, malts, scotch like, smoke like, peat, and fruits.  The look is brown to red in color, ok beige colored head, and clear.  The taste is fruits, malts, sweet, peats, caramel, smoke, and alcohol. Good and smooth.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 Location: 750 ml bottle from Whole Foods - Bowery, 2/9/11


Aroma: The nose is malty sweet with caramel, roasted notes, and some dark fruits/raisins

Appearance: Its dark brown with a slight redness to it and only a tiny amount of bubbly tan head

Flavor: Fairly sweet, flavors of the nose, not as much hop presence as I noted on draft

Palate: The drinkability remains high here, it is medium-full bodied, with a soft (almost flat) carbonation

Overall Impression: 
Since I saw this one in Whole Foods a few months back, and it has now been about a year after I tried this one for the first time on draft at the brewery, I thought it might be a good time for re-rate.  Anyway, this stuff wasnt quite as spectacular as I had remembered, but it is still a really good beer.  Well average the scores together (rounding up!) to make a composite thats slightly lower then before, but still quite high. (7/4/8/4/15)



Location: On tap at the Brewery, 1/8/10 


Aroma: Rich malty nose, lots of fruit notes, caramel, toffee, and earth

Appearance: Hazy reddish-brown color with a tan head

Flavor: Lots of malty sweetness, balanced by a nice hop flavor

Palate: Full bodied, crisp, slight alcohol burn, warming finish

Overall Impression: 
This beer is quite good.  One of the best, if not the best, Scotch Ale Ive ever had.  Really good stuff.  AleSmith does it again.  Im so glad I got to try so many beers on my visit, and I wish I could have more access to this one.  (8/4/9/4/17)

Bottle 2005 vintage. A thousand thanks to HogtownHarry. Dark ruby pour with thick lasting cream head. Aroma is, darn this actually smells like scotch! Molasses, smoke, rich malts something almost imperial stout-like about this one. Taste is so rich, very sweet but not too sticky there is a nice roasted bitter (dark chocolate) finale to cut it off. Palate is very nice, quite creamy, full and very long. The only thing I might have against this beer is that the taste is a tad thin, Id like to try a *fresh* version to compare.
Amber brown with a large tan head. Aroma is of toffee, peat, and malt. Taste is of toffee, malt, caramel, and peat.

Aroma is sweet, malty, light alcohol scent but not overpowering.  The color is    a dark mahogany hue, deeper than a nut brown but lighter than a porter.  Malty sweet up front with chocolate smoke finish.  a complex beer and another winner from alesmith

750 ml bottle poured into snifter.  Nice ruby brown color with frothy tan head.  Aroma of roast caramel malt, chocolate, molasses, bread, dark fruits, smoke.  Taste is lightly sweet and bitter, and a bit smokey.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel with crisp carbonation.  This was a very nice sipper, Id like more of this!

750 mL bottle from South Bay Drugs (purchased October 2009).  Muddy brown pour that looks almost black by the time it reaches the glass.  About a 1 inch thick creamy tan head.  Sweet aroma that honestly smells like Scotch whiskey as much as anything.  Some caramel and chocolate is also detected.  Big sweetness from this one as I would have expected from the style.  A very smooth and pleasant chocolate finish lingers on the palate.  As far as a Scotch Ale is concerned this absolutely nails it.  I have stated this before that this is not one of my favorite styles typically, but this really gets it right.

750 ml bottle from Dilly Deli.  Pours a very dark brown with a subtle reddish tint and a small tan head that never amounts to much.  Aroma of caramel malts, butterscotch, Scotch, chocolate, molasses, hops, plum, dark cherries, dates, and figs.  The flavor somehow improves upon the great aroma, and never lets the Scotch overwhelm notes of molasses, roasted caramel malts, chocolate, smoked wood, dark fruits (cherries, figs, plums, dates- same ones as in the nose), earthy hops, butterscotch, and soda bread.  So smooth and rich, full-bodied, with low carbonation.  More smoke and roast in the flavor than in the nose, which struck me as unusual.  Very cool big beer, interesting to drink and share.  AleSmith never ceases to impress.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 660ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Winter beers 2009) - shared by mjs - thanks!
Sweet aroma, some honey on toast. Smooth palate, soft carbonation. Nothing wee heavy-like about this at all. Caramel and honey everywhere. Palate also has burnt bitterness, I guess thats what they think is the scottish connection. Theres quite a nettley bite, which is the only real negative. Otherwise pretty solid. Perhaps a bit too sweet, but thats the only way they can restrain the alcohol.
Rerate: 750ml bottle (the 200e of overpriced shit session) (7:4:8:4:15=3.8)
Slightly oxidised aroma, nicely mellow. Deep brown, small tight head. Soft palate. Sweetish caramel malts. Very mellow, no heaviness at all. Very enjoyable. A sipper, but not too heavy to want a larger glass of. Overpricedness rating for 25e: 7/7

caramel, dried fruit, toffee, raison aromas .. . somewhat muddled yet sweet and enjoyable taste .. pretty fuckin big, some tartness, grrrr .. . rock n roll .. . what potential this brew has, but im not seeing it.. happy 2 have tried it..

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2011  Bottled. Pours slightly hazy and mahogany with an off-white head. Lovely malty nose with dark fruits and notes of hops. Flavour of carmel, roasted malt, dark fruits and chocolate. Full bodied. Creamy texture. Slightly bitter finish.

22-oz bottle NapaCabs (20090101) - Aroma: sweet, chocolate, licorice, dried fruit, alcoholic; Appearance: clear, dark-brown color, tan head, lots of laces; Flavor, sweet, salty, caramel, raisin, chocolate, nutty; Mouthfeel: full bodied, lively carbonation, thick-creamy texture; Overall: extraordinarily pleasantly rich, smooth, and complexity of warm alcohol, dried fruit, and deeply malty big beer balanced with medium-dry chewy, deep chocolate finish.
10.03.09 Bottle.  Pours brown with tan head.  Aroma of malt, maple syrup, dried fruits, slight tartness.  Tastes immediately sweet, fruity, maple syrup, slight smoke, malty, alcohol burn.

Strong caramalt aroma.  Deep brown color.  Sweet with an alcohol finish and a bit of red apple through the middle.

 Notes: 09 GABF

Botella. Batch 329. Deep dark brown colour with a beige head laving a good lacing. Sweet deep malty dark fruity chocolate aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with a deep maltiness, dark fruits, alcohol, chocolate and a very pleasant bitterness.

Bottled (thanks stoutlover72). Dark ambery brown colour with mediumsized beigeish brown head. Quite big maltyness along with some toffee and alcohol. Quite strong on the chocolate and nuttynesss as well. Flavour is quite much the same in a very fullbodied way. The alcohol is a bit too strong even though this has been kept since I got it in 2006.

Clear, dark amber with a small, partly lasting head. Neutral-malty aroma with grainy maltiness, a touch of alcohol, and some dried fruit. Neutral flavor with strong maltiness held well in balance, the overall presentation being surprisingly dry for the body. Quite full-bodied with medium carbonation. A big beer, but by no means extreme. Seems a bit overrated here, but it is very tasty.

Bottle. Rating no. 1700. Dark reddish brown body with a medium beige head. The aroma is chocolate, hops, barley malt, caramel and tons of toffee. The flavour is lots of dark fruit, dried fruit, toffee, chocolate, caramel and vanilla. Very complex but still balanced. Creamy texture. I could sip this for hours. Great beer.

Really beautiful dark ruby pour.  Alcohol well hidden for the most part until the aftertaste and subsequent warming affect.  Two finger airy tan head that faded fast.  Aroma - boozy warmed dates.  Flavor - a hint of the aroma but boozier.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured deep dark brown and almost clear with medium sized and white head. Aroma contained malts, treacle and chocolate. Palate was full bodied and quite dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, roastedness, molasses, chocolate, dried plum and bitterness. Aftertaste contained malts and dried plum. Beer showed several features of Scottish ale and still wasnt one. Still a very good beer.

Bottled (Pikkulintu, 0,75 ltr)
Dark brown-ruby color, small beige head. Sticky caramelly, toffeish (fudge) aroma. Smooth palate. Caramel, some alcohol (not much as 10%), some harsh malty(?) notes. A bit like dunkel in drugs. Not worth of praise but not bad.

cloudy brown, smooth light brown head.
aroma is dark fruits, roasted grains, almost porter like.,  dark caramel
flavor is very well blended. sweet malty, dark caramel, faint hops, ends malty sweet, well balanced by bitter chocoalty notes.
Ruby red colored brew. Nice aroma of chocolate, raisins, some sweetness, caramel. Flavor of raisins, chocolate malts and some caramel, nice. Good brew.

Big bottle from Hi-Time. Dark amber ruby body with stick head. Nose of raisins and caramel. Taste of malts, caramel and then nice chocolates. Really crisp and full-flavoured. Nice ABV towards the end. Great Scotch flavours. Well done, California.

The Dan Journal #309.  Tasted 10/3/09.  750ml bottle.  Filtered with a dark maple amber hue.  Webbed off-white head.  Aromas of raisins and spices.  Nutty and doughy.  Very nice nose.  Full bodied and sweet and spicy.  Sticky.  Wonderful complexity.  Flavors of raisins and port.  Vanilla and graham crackers.  Mild caramel note.  Good bitter finish.  Rolling and complex palate.  Very well done!  Great drinking!

Pours a muddy reddish-brown with thick biege head that displays solid retention.  Lacing is also very admirable.  Nose is punctuated by a smell of wet barley (like straight from the tun), molasses and as odd this may sound, merlot.  Flavor is complex, a melding of brown sugar, smoke, peat and dark cherries.  Full bodied with a great mouthfeel.  Very drinkable for a double digit abv, heat is almost non-existent.  Another alesmith offering that I really enjoyed.

Dark ruby-colored with a small off-white head that leaves lacings that stays around to the end which is quite impressive for a beer of this size.

The aroma is of sweet malts, lots of caramel, fruity notes and a gentle touch of alcohol.

Theres delicious malts all around in the flavor. Very complex malt profile. Some bready notes, but most of all lots of caramel. With a complementary fruitiness, that has a very gentle tart character (perhaps caused by cellaring), I get a sensation similar to hard fruit candy. The finish as mildly bitter with more notes of malts, a gentle roasted note and some alcohol. The alcohol is nicely hidden and well integrated.

Medium body with a slick texture.

A well crafted beer. Very impressive malty profile and surprisingly easy to drink.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

From the Bottle at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 27/09/2009
Big bourbon aroma. Amber mid brown coloured and strong in alcohol with a smooth and slightly dry warming malt finish.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2009. Dark brown color. Thick sweet, very raisiny and warming aroma. Sweet, raisiny and toffeish flavor. Nicely warming palate. Good dark fruit character. Very drinkable despite the strength and sweetness,
4th September 2008. Cloudy brown beer. Starts with an even mix of salty malt and smooth chocolate. Finishes with a chocolate and hop mix and some alcohol warmth. Complex and tasty!
Dark brown pour with plenty of tan lacy foam. Sweet, smooth and chocolaty flavor with a dry and bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2010 Nose is complex with figs, dark chocolate and toast. Astounding! Flavorful palate, dynamic with a long finish. 

This bottle looks and tastes like it has some age on it. A truly great find.

Bottled. Hazy brown color, medium head. Aroma of some roasted and caramel malt, some hop, chocolat, hint of raisin. Malty taste, quite fruity, bit chocolat. All with the great balance of most alesmith brews. Nice.
Bottle @ kloneo, thx caesar. Aroma of toasted malts, chocolate and molasses. Flavour is toasted malts, molasses and raisins. Long finish. Good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2009 0,75 l bottle, thanks Chimay67!
Fantastic appearance with a deep brown body and a creamy beige head. Fine aroma of coffee and molasses, nice cocoa and dried fruits, light hop. The body is rich with smooth mouthfeel....Fine roasted grains, caramel, toffee and mild hop, some wooden taste with dried fruits and cocoa. Well hidden alcohol warms me up. Fine, very fine!

Bottled. Tnx Caesar. The aroma has yeast, caramel, raisins and some hops. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet with caramel, raisin, toffee. Good cmplex caramel flavours. Well balanced beer.

Split the bottle with my older brother at Rattle n Hum. Was hesitant at first because I hadnt had a scotch ale in a while, but after the pour I my hesitation went away. The nice head, great toffee and caramel aroma, and spicy/toffee/nutty taste were great. for 10% ABV this beer was quite drinkable.

750ml Bottle. Deep dark brown with tan frothy head that looks like cappuccino and leaves a sticky lace. Aroma is dominantly caramel with bittersweet chocolate, plum, alcohol and a bit of smoke. The flavor is malty and sweet but surprisingly very bitter, a chocolate, coffee and hop bitterness. The alcohol is well hidden but warms the stomach. Full bodied with average carbonation and a thick velvety mouth feel. This is a nice rich desert beer.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2009 Thanks to lamas for this 750 mL Champagne Magnum (?2007 vintage) for rating #500.  Been cellaring this one for well over 2 years.  Poured mahogany with fizzy khaki head with a few splotches of lacing.  BIG, sweet malty flavor.  Some dark fruit, chocolate, and definitive coffee notes evident as well.  Silky texture.  Remarkably smooth.  Holy fuck, thanks brah!

750ml capped and foiled from kegbear.  Deep dark brown with maybe the best looking tan head of any Scotch ale I have ever had.  Starts out big with tight uniform bubbles and settles down to a thin layer and will reform easily with a little swirl of my glass.  Malt, peat, fleshy plum, cola.  Tight sharp carbonation on the tongue with thick but proper body and oily feel.  Prickly up front with bready malt that quickly moved into peat then sweet plum, dates and cola finishing up with more peat, tobacco and leather.  If I have to knock it for anything, it would be that the alcohol is a bit sharp.  Thanks Craig!

Dark mahogany pour with ruby highlights and a big, frothy, off-white head.  The aroma is peat smoke and caramel with notes of molasses, dates, and a whiff of alcohol.  The flavor adds in some allspice, burnt almond and ends with a nice lingering peat smoke.  Creamy full body with soft carbonation.

Bottle 2009 into mini pint glass.  Very dark brown with a nice creamy khaki head.  This one is just very solid on the aroma and flavor with lots of roasty malt notes, caramel, a bit of smoke, and some residual sweetness that isnt overwhelming.  A nice toasty winter drinker with a heavy and smooth mouthfeel.

Dark brown color with a small white head. Nice aroma of malt, dried fruits, caramel, chocolate. Malty and sweet flavor, fruits, nuts, bourbon. Well balanced and complex. Alcohol was well hidden, thick with a full body. Great!

750ml split with CUJO.  Amazed I forgot to rate this 3 months ago when I originally had this.  Paraphrased from cujos review...  Great looking pour, dark cola/coffee in color leaving a full finger of thick dry head. Nose is very complex with dark fruits, cooked sugars/malts. First sip reveals strong booze. After more tasting the mouth relaxes and reveals its complexity, again with the dark fruits, nice bitterness in the hops. As it got warmer more earthiness is drawn out, the woods/ pines come through. The lacing in the glass was surprising, a dark dry film had to be scratched off the glass. Not the deity I was expecting, but a great complex and balanced beer no doubt.

Champagne magnum. 2005 Vintage.  Pours a deep viscous mahogany with no head. Multi-layered candied sugar nose with a heavy dose of burnt caramel. Flavor shows notes of slightly burnt malt, smoked peat, candied raisins and hints of vanilla. Body has an impresse depth with a minimal level of carbonation and a rich, syrupy texture. The alcohol is well hidden and the finish is smooth with a lingering note of burnt sugar.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Rating # 500 and to celebrate my little milestone my first Alesmith, bottle thanks to Ryan (giascar) I have been sitting on this one for a while,so lets see what all the rave is about.Pours brown with a ruby hue with avery lively tan head that is so thick you can make peaks with your finger,with a full bodied appearence so far so good,following form for a scotch ale,aromas are of very heavy caramelized malts, smoke,vanilla and a very faint aroma of hops well in the back ground just where they belong taste is of a very powerful malt bomb,sweet smooth,sugar vanilla, this by far is the best I have had in this style even if magic dave says there is no such thing as scotch ale  lives up to the hype and I m very jealous of all the fellow ratebeerians who can buy this at thier local bottle shops
Pours a dark brown color with just a little white head to it. Has a amazing maltybutterscotch smell to it. Taste is more or less the same as the smell but with a smokey finish to it.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2013 Pitcher pour at 2009 GABF. Pours a thin beige, dissipating head, over a clear (SRM 12) body.....nose is mild cherry, toffee, caramel, some coffee, some chocolate....taste is sweet malts, dried fruit (fig), slight coffee, chocolate....mouth feel is medium, carbonation low. Tasting 9/26/09. 2013 tasting. Bottle. Pours medium, well retained light beige head, with some lacing, over a clear brown (SRM 20) body......nose is plum, raisin, hints of cherry, cocoa, treacle, minimal hops.....taste is sweet malts with toffee/caramel, cherry, plum, raisin, finishing almost dry, with minimal hop bitterness....mouth feel thick, sticky, alcohol heat present, carbonation low. Rich, thick sweet with great malt complexity in both nose and taste with minimal hop contribution is a "Wee Heavy". BJCP 8/3/16/5/8
Tasting at GABF. Light/medium brown with thin white head. Alcohol prevalent in nose and taste. Balanced wet bitter finish. Coffee  notes heavy. NOthing to the speed way stout.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of dark bread, toasted and milk chocolate, herbs and burnt orange for the hops, dough and earth for the yeast, with background notes of charcoal, dark brown sugar and cola. Head is average size, frothy, light brown with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear dark mahogany. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter.
